ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed my skills in jazz improvisation, specifically my command of the bebop scale, pivoting, and other bebop techniques.
Learned invaluable skills that are easy to understand and implement, such as the bebop scale and its corresponding chord tone rules. Also learned pivoting, a similarly important bebop technique.

I gained a huge amount of music theory skill in understanding chord changes, how different chords relate to their key signatures, how to break down the chord changes of a tune, how to figure out what notes to play over certain chords, and specific techniques to gain bebop language and improve soloing.
Learned the bebop scale, pivoting, and practiced transcription.

Learn jazz improvisation by transcribing solos, studying bebop and pivoting, writing our own solos, and performing the music ourselves. Even though I did not have as much time to practice as I would have liked, I learned a lot of techniques that I can practice on my own.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths:
Professor Escoffery gives me goosebumps every time he plays. He comes from the old bebop tradition, but is of course well-versed in every aspect of jazz and its theory. Assignments are all reasonable and help you learn a lot. 

Weakness:
Very few. Only wish class wasn't so early in the morning.

The course is extremely strong. Professor Escoffery is very talented and beyond that, is eager to share his knowledge. Because of the setup of the class, it is not the strongest environment for practicing technical skills on your instrument, but that is not the goal of the class and can be done individually in a practice room. The goal of this class, which is achieves strongly, is to improve musical knowledge and more specifically jazz improvisation skills in a way which can be applied individually.

Could use more written resources as all the theory was verbally communicated and if you missed something there was no way of knowing. More in class playing would be good, sometimes we ended early and instead we could have played at least

Strengths: Professor Escoffery is an excellent teacher and explains the music theory while also giving us very practical performance skills so that we can play this important music and use it in our own expression. The music curriculum at Yale could be improved by offering more jazz classes like this one and more opportunities to study and practice jazz.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely! The class was fun and engaging, and the classroom atmosphere was positive and helpful.
Most definitely yes yes yes. Even if just to take it as an opportunity to hear Prof. Escoffery play. I genuinely feel more competent in jazz now. Just need to practice more.
Yes its a fun chill class and you are forced to do transcriptions which are essential for jazz.

If you are interested in jazz and have some background in improvising, definitely! This is an excellent course that gives students both theory and practical skills. Yale should really offer more jazz classes.
